qas.question: What acted as a physical obstacle to anti-aircraft defence?
What were barrage balloons initially used as an obstacle to?
How was a barrage balloon tethered to the ground?
What did pilots have to do to avoid the barrage balloons?
What kind of success did barrage balloons have as far as bringing down aircraft?

context: Another aspect of anti-aircraft defence was the use of <a0_0>barrage balloons<a0_0/> to act as physical obstacle initially to <a1_0>bomber aircraft over cities<a1_0/> and later for ground attack aircraft over the Normandy invasion fleets. The balloon, a simple blimp tethered to the ground, worked in two ways. Firstly, it and the <a2_0>steel cable<a2_0/> were a danger to any aircraft that tried to fly among them. Secondly, to avoid the balloons, bombers had to <a3_0>fly at a higher altitude<a3_0/>, which was more favorable for the guns. Barrage balloons were limited in application, and had <a4_0>minimal<a4_0/> success at bringing down aircraft, being largely immobile and passive defences.
